main_definition: An auction is a public sale in which goods or property are sold to the highest bidder.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A method of selling items by inviting people to make bids, with the item going to the highest bidder at the conclusion of the auction.
meanings_and_examples.example: The antique painting was sold at an auction for $1 million.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A type of competition where individuals or groups offer increasingly higher bids to win a prize.
meanings_and_examples.example: During the charity auction, several people bid against each other for rare collectible coins as they wanted to support the cause.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A legal process involving the sale of property or assets through an open public bidding
meanings_and_examples.example: The bank held a foreclosure auction and sold the house at a price significantly lower than its market value due to unpaid mortgage.

meanings_and_examples.definition: An event where items are offered for sale, typically with a starting bid set by an organizer or seller.
meanings_and_examples.example: The art gallery hosted an auction of local artists' works and started the bidding at $100 per piece.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A business model where goods are sold based on demand, with prices fluctuating according to customer interest.
meanings_and_examples.example: The online retailer uses a dynamic auction pricing strategy for their electronics section, allowing customers to bid for items at various price points.
